0: So while the long-term effects of the leak may not amount to much, in the short term the problem has caused mayhem. Erin Brockovich, the environmental activist who successfully took Pacific Gas and Electric Company to task over groundwater contamination, has held community meetings to discuss the leak’s effects. The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered a no-fly-zone over Porter Ranch for safety reasons. The leak, buried deep in the ground at a giant gas field that stores energy for distribution around Southern California, now accounts for about 25 percent of the methane emitted in California each day. Methane is a highly potent greenhouse gas that contributes to climate change. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In declaring the state of emergency, Mr. Brown said that he acted in response to the “prolonged and continuing” nature of the leak, which was detected Oct. 23. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Video NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR To those whose lives have been upended by the leak, the situation has long qualified as a disaster, and the governor’s delay has been one of many sources of frustration. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Sharon Mousavi-Dormani is among those who have moved away temporarily, with her dog and two children, after choking on the fumes for more than a month and suffering from headaches, sore throats and nosebleeds. Even the dog was getting diarrhea, she said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR With hotels in the area full over the holidays, the family members found themselves at a hotel in Pasadena, about 30 miles away, unsure where they would end up or what schools the children would attend, given that the ones in Porter Ranch have closed because of the problem. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “It’s like a fog in your brain — it feels like you’re having a stroke,” Ms. Mousavi-Dormani said of how she feels every time she returns to her home, as she did recently to help prepare for the heavy rainstorms that fell in the region last weekend as a consequence of El Niño. “Every time I go back, I get sicker and sicker.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Many who have stayed have taken to wearing surgical masks when they garden to keep out the rotten-egg smell and the oily mist that sometimes leaves brown residue on their cars. Temporary signs dot the street urging residents to report suspicious activities. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “The neighborhood was a safe place to have your kids grow up,” said Amber Visage, 27, explaining why she moved to Porter Ranch with her daughter, now 6. She has relocated to a hotel and is worried about the value of her home, along with her family’s health. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Photo NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Who would want to move here now?” she asked. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Southern California Gas Company, a division of Sempra Energy of San Diego, has been subsidizing those residents who want to move and installing air filtration for those who choose to stay. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Officials from the company declined to say how much has been spent addressing the leak or how they plan to address the lawsuits that will probably haunt them for years. At least two law firms representing residents have filed suit against the company, as has the Los Angeles city attorney. Mr. Brown’s sister, Kathleen L. Brown, is a Sempra Energy board member. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Company officials insisted they were doing everything possible to plug the leak quickly, adding that leading engineers from around the country had been brought in to assist. A relief well under construction to fix the problem will have to reach more than 8,000 feet underground so engineers can inject additional liquids and then permanently cap the leaking well with cement, company officials said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “We’re working literally 24 hours a day,” said Dennis Arriola, the president of Southern California Gas Company. “People get frustrated if they don’t understand the principles, but we’re going on schedule.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He added that experts had “never seen anything like this.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Unlike some other wells, the leaking well did not have an subsurface safety valve.
